summary: So okay it's just a work in progress and I didn't want to put it out there just yet, but here i am. Really proud of...
body: So okay it’s just a work in progress and I didn’t want to put it out there just yet, but here i am. Really proud of @danielhowell and I feel every word he said in his video with my quite not so wholesome heart. I love how everyone is supportive of each other and it fills me with joy ❤ I really want to wish Happy Pride everyone! It means the world to me when totally unknown people in the internet can make such a strong bond even not knowing each other. Love it. Love all of you. Love is love, just feel it in your heart. We’re here, we’re queer, we have an existential fear lmao 🏳️‍🌈❤🧡💛💚💙💜

summary: I wonder how long the lesters have known and how much they actually know. It would be really awesome if all this time that dan...
body: I wonder how long the lesters have known and how much they actually know. It would be really awesome if all this time that dan has gone with them on family trips and spent holidays with them that they’ve been a save haven for the both of them but especially dan who didn’t have that with his own family. I would just be so happy to know they were there for him when he didn’t feel like he could be himself around his own family.

summary: Tw// suicide, depression, anxiety, self harm, abuse
body:
Tw// suicide, depression, anxiety, self harm, abuse

Thank you, @danielhowell, for sharing such an intimate part of your life with us.

Your business is your business but I applaud and thank you for being open about it and making so many people more happy with themselves.

This video has saved lives.

Your coming out was the beautiful beginning to so many others.

Your coming out was the push some people needed.

Your coming out was what made so many people finally come to terms with who they are.

And when I use the term “coming out” I don’t only mean your sexuality; I’m talking about all of it. The abuse, trauma, depression, anxiety, fear, self harm, suicide, and every other horrible side effect of not knowing who you are. You make me want to live my truth and I cannot thank you enough for that. You talking the way you did about your suicide attempt and the terrifying reality of it all, truly gives me hope. I’ve been very seriously contemplating suicide. I felt completely lost, alone, and afraid; but you make me believe I can get better.

Thank you, Dan.

In the words of Captain Holt; “Every time someone steps up and says who they are, the world becomes a better, more interesting place”

blog.description: we’re here, we’re queer, we’re filled with existential fear

summary: I still don’t have words to say because it will just be all jumbled and maybe I’ll never find the right words. But even though I...
body: I still don’t have words to say because it will just be all jumbled and maybe I’ll never find the right words. But even though I only started watching Dan and Phil almost 5 years ago (wow, seems shorter than that) I’ve seen them both grow so much as people. And that’s not to mention how much they have grown since first starting youtube. Especially in the last 2 years, they have become more confident in themselves, proud of the content they are creating, and now they have reached a point where they are starting to embrace who they are. I’m just so proud of them both. I know this year has had a rocky start but it all makes sense, this whole after tour hiatus makes sense. I’m thrilled to see what will happen after vidcon because I think we’re going to see the most honest version of Dan and Phil we’ve ever seen.

Especially in the last 2 years, they have become more confident in themselves, proud of the content they are creating, and now they have reached a point where they are starting to embrace who they are. I’m thrilled to see what will happen after vidcon because I think we’re going to see the most honest version of Dan and Phil we’ve ever seen.

summary: i can relate to dan struggling with the word gay and being afraid to call himself 'gay' because of his trauma connected to it so...
body: i can relate to dan struggling with the word gay and being afraid to call himself ‘gay’ because of his trauma connected to it so much. it used to be the exact same way for me with the word 'lesbian’. thinking of myself as a lesbian (let alone calling myself one) made me feel incredibly disgusting. i was ashamed of my sexuality and i hated the word 'lesbian’ because to me it was synonymous with 'bad’ and 'dirty’. but the only way to get through that, to accept yourself the way you are is to face this word, to reclaim it and to learn to love it. i am proud to say i am a lesbian and i am incredibly proud of dan and of how far he has come.
